guidelines: Contact the right person before every call. Ask for the decision-maker by name and confirm you are speaking with them.
Use the first ten seconds to prove there is value in staying on the line. Lead with the outcome you can deliver.
Keep the conversation personable and grounded in genuine curiosity. Reference shared details when possible.
Talk about the prospect more than yourself. Ask about their priorities, pressures, and current approach.
Stay goal-focused. Know whether you are booking a meeting, collecting info, or qualifying interest and gently steer back to that goal.
Use trigger events (new hires, launches, partnerships) to show relevance and timeliness.
Ask open-ended questions that start with who/what/where/when/how/why to keep them talking.
Avoid pitching too early. Discover a pain or confirming need before presenting a solution.
Be specific about the value you offer and the next steps you need.
Ask for referrals when someone says no or after a win—make it easy to introduce you.
Always leave a concise voicemail (<20s) that is friendly, personal, and creates curiosity without a hard sell.
tips: Be an active listener—mirror key phrases back to show you heard them.
Set expectations immediately: who you are, why you called, and how long it takes.
Identify the prospect's pain points early so you can tailor the conversation.
Showcase what makes you different without dismissing competitors.
Ask thoughtful discovery questions to uncover day-to-day realities.
Share proof or stats that map directly to the pain they mention.
Leverage social proof such as testimonials or recognizable wins.
Explain the next step while you still have them engaged.
Plan strategic follow-ups and schedule them while you talk if possible.
Use technology (CRM, call logs, automations) to track every touch.
Call with timing that respects their workflow and industry rhythm.
Stay goal-focused—know what 'success' for this call looks like.
Be empathetic, especially if you interrupted something important.
Continuously improve by reviewing recordings and updating scripts.

scripts.uninterested: Hello, {{name}}. This is {{agent}} from {{company}}. I’ll be brief—{{specialty}} is what we do best. In just three minutes I can show how we help companies like yours {{value}} using {{feature_list}}. Does that sound fair?
scripts.stretch_prospect: Hi {{name}}, this is {{agent}} from {{company}}. I was hoping to talk about {{topic}} if you have a minute. I speak with teams like yours all the time and they keep running into {{pain}}. How have you been managing that recently? (listen) Sounds like we could be helpful—can we set up time next week to dig in?
scripts.gatekeeper: Hi {{gatekeeper}}. My name is {{agent}} with {{company}}. I’m looking to speak with {{prospect}} or whoever leads {{department}}. Would you mind transferring me or sharing the best number/email for them?
scripts.no_time: Thanks for letting me know it’s not a good moment. I can call back {{time}} unless there’s a better window for you. It will only take a couple of minutes and I’ll come prepared so it’s worth it.
scripts.referral: I completely understand, {{name}}. Before I let you go, is there anyone in your network who’s battling {{pain}} and might value a quick chat with us? I’d really appreciate an intro or even just their contact info. Either way, thank you for your time.
scripts.voicemail: Hi {{name}}, this is {{agent}} with {{company}}. I’ll be brief—I noticed {{trigger}} and I have an idea that could help you {{outcome}}. Give me a call back at {{callback}} and I’ll keep it under two minutes. Talk soon!
